title: A New York County Executive Aims to Boost Service-Minded Candidates
sub_head: Assistance will be offered to veterans, as well as first responders and other essential workers
body:
When Pat Ryan campaigned for Congress in 2018, the West Point graduate got invaluable help from national groups dedicated to supporting veterans running for office.
Now, as the Ulster County executive, Mr. Ryan has formed a political-action committee to help nontraditional candidates break into politics. The Democratic executive said in a recent interview that the PAC, called ServeNY, has raised close to $300,000 and would be endorsing Democratic office seekers around New York. It will offer advice and financial assistance to veterans as well as first responders and other essential workers.
“People question whether the motivations of their elected officials are self-serving or selfless,” he said. “There needs to be more on-ramps for service-minded people to get into office.”
The PAC’s first endorsements will go to Felicia Singh, a special-education teacher running for New York City Council in Queens; Sarah Klee Hood, an Air Force veteran running for town board in the Syracuse suburb of DeWitt; and Anthony Grice, a teacher and Newburgh City Council member who is running for Orange County clerk.
The PAC is also a way for Mr. Ryan, a Kingston, N.Y., native, to raise his profile and establish a network of allies beyond his Hudson Valley base. More endorsements are expected in coming weeks, he said.
